Mr H’s hams
3 – 12 – 4 ½ This running log of DW’s purchases follows the conventional pounds-shillings-pence bookkeeping format. See left side of scan in figure 1.

Miss Greenhow for D This unspecified purchase for Dora (D) possibly came from Ann Greenhow of Kendal, who specialized in wrappers, twine, and other packaging products (see WG, 8 June 1822).
11 – 6
Blank silk for Dr &
Ws handkerchief Presumably gifts for DW’s brothers Christopher (D r) and WW (W).
– – 11 – 3
Teaspoons 2 – 6
Turnpikes &c 1 – –
Miss [Cherberleys?] 7 – 6

p.note: A curatorial note in pencil and a hand other than DW’s that references this notebook’s detailed account of her July 1825 trip to Ulverston.

div.p:
Wednesday December 1st, 1824
Ground thinly covered with snow. Snow showers – rain – hail. Walk before dinner, The major daily meal, usually eaten between 2:00 and 4:00 p.m. during this period. GJ suggests that, at least two decades earlier, the Wordsworths typically dined closer to 2:00 p.m. (60).
with M & W. After to Mr Carr’s – – still hail-showers – frosty moonlight returning with Mr & Mrs Carr. Fine clouds Day & Night.

Thursday 2nd Bright morning. Hills & valley white – With Mary at Mr Elliotts – very cold there[.] Walk first with W – then alone under Crags Nab Scar, roughly a mile northwest of Rydal Mount.
in Sun & after Dinner with Wm – –

Friday 3rd
Still hard frost – not cloudless – Threating snow – Bottle wine Raisin wine (as clarified in ensuing entry). Cf. GJ, 19 (1 September 1800) and Letters, 3:409.
– With Wm. to Ambleside, after dinner

Saturday 4th
Clear frost – Bottled Raisin Wine – Dined at 2 – Wm at Grasmere meeting WW vocally opposed the proposed enclosure of waste and common lands in Grasmere and Loughrigg at several local meetings that winter (Letters, 4:304, 8:187–90).
– Walk with Willy to Ambleside – in wood by Scandal. Scandale Fell, roughly a mile northeast of Rydal.
Mr & Mrs Carr to tea The traditional British afternoon repast, usually taken at this time between 5:00 and 6:00 p.m. DW’s GJ entry for 13 February 1802 characterizes 7:30 p.m. as unusually late for tea (68).

Sunday 5th
Very bright morning – Alpine Lights on hills – Ambleside Church – Hartley Coleridge to dinner – Mr Marshall called. All day bright – glorious Moon – burr A circle of light or halo. round it & yesterday –

Monday 6th Decr
Thaw, heavy rain – clears before 4. Walk on Terrace The 250-yard-long terrace WW had developed upon moving to Rydal Mount for gazing upon Rydal Water and to have a place to pace as he wrote poetry. On 21 January 1825, he expressed his regrets to Lord Lonsdale for having been away when the lord had recently called, as he “should have liked much to show [him] the view from the garden and Terrace of Rydal Mount, which are universally admired” (Letters, 4:305–06).
– amber Clouds – To Ambleside with [ ] & Dora – Full Moon, tip toe, on dark Cloud – lost again. Rose by Candle light – W. too late for Coach The coach that was to take him and Dora to Keswick (see following entry). A coeval letter of MW reports how on this visit WW stayed with Robert Southey and Dora with “the solitary Mother of her friend Mary Calvert, who was married last Autumn” ( WT MS WLL / Wordsworth, Mary / 1 / 64).

Tuesday 7th
Dull morning – a little rain – went to Mrs Elliotts – letters from Wales Likely updates from Tom Hutchinson, MW’s brother who had just moved from Radnorshire, Wales, to Brinsop Court, Herefordshire, near the Welsh border.
&c – [Jos.?] Perhaps the Joseph referenced in Mary Ann Lloyd’s later account of how, in 1825, the Wordsworths’ staff included “Joseph the farming-boy who had the charge of the Pony, and when at Rydal the care of the Poultry” (WLMS A / Jewsbury, Maria Jane / 52).
goes by Coach. Wm & D follow on horseback – Showers – yellow brightness to the South[.] Walk on Terrace. Stormy ride to Keswick…

Wednesday 8th
Windy & showery – [nary?] out –. After dinner walked to Quarry Possibly the quarry on the eastern shore of Rydal Water near Nab Wood. Another nearby quarry is memorialized in the title of WW’s 1800 poem Lines Written with a Slate-Pencil upon a Stone, the Largest of a Heap Lying near a Deserted Quarry, upon One of the Islands at Rydale.
with Mary. – No rain. – Fanny Wilson. Letter from Dr W. DW and WW’s younger brother Dr. Christopher Wordsworth.

Thursday 9th
Fine morning. Sunshine, but soon a hail shower – All day showery & cold –. Wrote to Miss Horrocks Sarah Horrocks, whose sister Jane was married to Tom Monkhouse, MW’s seriously ill cousin. The Monkhouses and Sarah had gone to Torquay on the Devon coast hoping the sea air would improve Tom’s health. DW wrote on 13 December that “Miss Horrocks” had been “very good in sending [them] whatever tidings she receives from Torquay” (Letters, 4:291).
– a little rain going to Ambleside with M. Call at Mrs North’s[,] Mrs Carlton’s, Mary Chambers Carleton, whose husband, John, had died in Ambleside in 1820 at age 73 (WG, 18 November 1820). The family moved to the Lakes from Ireland in 1814 after John was charged with embezzling public funds in his capacity as a Dublin alderman (see Stewart, “ Carleton Family of Eustace Street”; “Alderman John Carleton, a Bankrupt,” Saunders’s News-Letter [Dublin], 16 February 1815).
Miss Knott’s, Thomas Troughton. Stationer and bookseller in Ambleside from ca. 1820 until his 1860 death (Kendal Mercury, 23 June 1860).
Bright frost at 11.

Friday 10th
Very keen bright frost – – continues – only hazy in the afternoon. Bottled wine – Miss M[ary] Dowling to dinner. Rainy night.

Saturday 11th
Misty rain – walked with M & Willy to Fox Ghyll – wrote Mrs Luff. Visiting Margaret De Quincey, who had just delivered her fifth child in the absence of her husband, Thomas. After this visit, DW updated Mrs. Luff on the De Quinceys’ timeline for leaving Fox Ghyll (see Letters, 4:282–83, 317–18).
Heavy rain at Keswick. Wm. & Dora cannot come on horseback – arrive in Coach. J W. arrives. John Wordsworth, returning from Oxford for the holidays (LMW, 121). Partly over fears of a typhus outbreak in Oxford, he would not return to school until after Easter (Letters, 4:292, 298).
Sunday 12th – Very warm & mild. All at Church but Dora & Willy. – They at Ambleside. Called at Col. Campbell’s, very wet returning.

Monday 12th After incorrectly dating consecutive entries the 12th, DW’s numbering would be off for several weeks. She later corrected the dates for 19–22 December but neglected to change those from the previous week.
Very dark morning. – Breakfast at 8. Probably specifies the hour because the leisured classes of this period generally did not eat breakfast until 9:00 or 10:00 a.m.
– Rain all day. – – wrote letters, walked on Terrace, while Wm & J go to Ambleside – dark night

Tuesday 13th
Very rainy – all day. Began Dante. DW’s abiding interest in Dante is evidenced in her copious, undated notes on his life and works in DCMS 119.

Wednesday 14th
Rain! Rain! I went to Miss Dowlings &c. – Chaises going. Mr Cowper Likely the Ambleside tradesman DW mentioned in a 27 March 1821 letter (Letters, 4:52).
very ill – Starlight at 11 – & frost

Thursday 15th
Beautiful rose-coloured sky. Mild morning – no frost[.] Fox Ghyll with W at ½ past 1. Mrs Carlton – Rain comes on Terrace – wet evening.

Friday 16th
Rainy morning – not heavy. Peggy Wilkinson. Dante. Walk on Terrace after dinner 2 hours – a little Rain. Coach Lamps – Mrs Robinsons to supper Generally, a lighter meal eaten at 9:00 or 10:00 p.m.

Saturday
17th
Very Dark morning. Misly Drizzling. rain. Meeting at G[rasmere]. See note for 4 December. Mr Harrison Anthony Harrison, a friend of WW’s since their time at Hawkshead grammar school and now a Penrith solicitor, part-time poet, and agent for Lord Lonsdale.
&c. – – Wet all day. –

Sunday 18 19th Wm. to Lowther[.] I in Chaise to Ambleside After Harrison spent the night of 17 December at Rydal Mount, he and WW made the 23-mile trip to Penrith in his chaise, dropping DW off in Ambleside en route. WW was visiting his ailing associate, Rev. James Clarke Satterthwaite, one of the region’s most influential Tories (Letters, 4:304; LMW, 120–21).
– Mr Carr’s – Rain all day
Monday 19 20th Bright sunrise – rain comes on –. With M to Ivy Cot, & Scandal Hill. Cold, sleety, hail & rain all day. Lightning as [ ] [later rain?]

Tuesday 20 21st
Fresh snow on [waking?]. Fine morning – Blue sky & large clouds – heavy rain comes on. Party at Betty’s. Hail showers &c &c

Wednesday 21st 22nd
Dark morning. After breakfast on Terrace – [All?] the rest of the day – Rain, sleet, &c &c – [ ] wind [–] frosty night

Thursday 22nd
Sudden keen frost – very bright. Wm. expected – [up to?] Ambleside with John[,] Dora Mr Barber’s

Friday 24
No frost – sunshine – – at Mr E[lliott]’s with Julia. Dora reported on 27 December, “Julia Myers . . . is spending her Holy days with us” ( WT MS WLL / Wordsworth, Dora / 1 / 6).
Wm arrives Returning from the visit to Lowther for which he had departed on 19 December.
–

Christmas Day DW’s fifty-third birthday. Storm – wind rain flood – Chapel opened Of the torrential rain that spoiled the opening of the new Rydal Chapel commissioned by Lady Ann le Fleming of Rydal Hall, Dora wrote, “I never was out in such a storm, nor does my Father ever remember experiencing so violent a one. . . . It was truly awful” ( WT MS WLL / Wordsworth, Dora / 1 / 6). WW grumbled that “the cost of the Structure has much exceeded what was needful” but conceded that “when time has softened down the exterior a little it will prove a great ornament to the Village grateful” (Letters, 4:301). MW considered it a great monument to the Village,” “notwithstanding all the blunders that have been made by the ignorance of the Builders” (LMW, 120). DW was less equivocal, saying that the hamlet was “beautified by our new Chapel which is a great comfort to us” (Letters, 4:396).
– Water [pills?] – Cards

Monday 26th Dates are again slightly off for the final five entries of December 1824, as the 26th was a Sunday, the 27th a Monday, and so forth.
Very dark – very wet morning. Party at Mr Robinson’s. Just fair for our walk thither[.] Mrs Carr in Chaise

Tuesday 27th
Fine day – rather frosty. Mr Douglass, Likely the same person DW alludes to in an April 1825 letter that mentions “Mr Douglas’s swindling tricks” (Letters, 4:340).
Mrs Elliotts[.] Moonlight walk to Ambleside. Very fine –

Wednesday 28th
Frosty – fine sun-rise – clear sky – To Fox Ghyll & Ambleside. Rain comes on in the evening, after Walk on Terrace
Thursday 29th – not frosty but fine day – rather windy – Rain at night

Friday 30th – William’s tooth drawn. The first of several dental extractions recorded in the RJ, adding to several in the GJ (e.g., pp. 12, 103, 133). During an 1820 visit to London, DW had paid 50 guineas to have her six remaining teeth pulled and replaced with dentures. WW would follow suit in 1836 (Barker, 534, 680).
Rainy morning. Fair to Mr Carr’s to dinner – very windy & very warm

New years day – Fine morning – to Church. To Mr Robinson’s. Mr J[ackson] On 10 December 1824, MW apologetically informed their old neighbor (and Dora’s future husband) Edward Quillinan, “In the course of the Holidays we shall have Mr Wm Jackson for our guest[;] therefore the Mount cannot receive you” ( WT MS WLL / Wordsworth, Mary / 1 / 64).
& Miss Hodson Possibly a relative of Frances Barlow, whose mother was a Hodson.
call – very wet afternoon

Sunday 2nd
Strong cold wind – I went to Grasmere Church[.] Rain in showers, in returning. Mary Party – first night MW seems to have hosted a New Year’s, or “First Night,” party.

Monday 3rd
Very Rainy all day – clear night. Mr R’s Twins born Although the Robinsons lived in Ambleside, the Cumberland Pacquet for 11 January 1825 listed their twins’ place of birth as Rydal. The delivery may have occurred, then, at Rydal Mount, which might explain Mr. Carr’s presence.
– – Mr Carr to dinner &c.

Tuesday 4th
Mary at Grasmere, I wrote letters for Wm. Among these was a lengthy letter to their brother Christopher (Letters, 4:296).
– to Miss Dowlings before dinner – dry cold wind – frosty night. Very clear

Wednesday 5th
Beautiful frosty day [–] Sunny. Mrs Hardens with Wm & over Loughrigg In his Guide to the Lakes, WW recommended this favorite route overlooking Grasmere Lake and Rydal Water, observing, “There are delightful rambles over every part of Loughrigg Fell and among the enclosures on its sides; particularly about Loughrigg Tarn, and on its eastern side about Fox How and the properties adjoining to the northwards” (link to our Guide ed., para. 15 of 1835 text).
– Reading [Madam?] [ ].

Thursday 6th
Dull morning – frosty. Calgarth & Troutbeck. Presumably visiting the Watsons and perhaps the Barlows.
Rain comes on – Detained in Troutbeck – Darkness, dull moonlight – misty rain

Friday 7th Jany. 1825
Rain & Mist. Clears in afternoon. After Dinner I walked to Grasmere. Met W & Mr Robinson. Bright frosty night.

Saturday 8th
Bright sun, inclining to frost. Walk with W & M to Fox Ghyll thro wood – on Terrace –.

Sunday 9th – Lovely day at Grasmere – clear & bright. Silvery Fogs on Rydal hills &c. – Wm Green Unidentified. While there were several Rev. William Green’s in Britain, none were in the northwest. Accordingly, this might have been Rev. Daniel Green, a son of Grasmere just then entering the ministry after graduating from St. Catherine’s Hall, Cambridge (see 27 July 1825 entry and Letters, 4:218n6).
preached. After [to?] Rydal church[,] at Mrs Robinsons & walk on Terrace. Clear there[.] Fogs below remind me of Rigi & Lenzberg. DW, WW, and MW visited Mount Rigi and Lenzburg in central Switzerland during their 1820 continental tour. DW’s 4 August 1820 entry in her Journal of a Tour on the Continent reads, “Lenzburg. . . . At six o'clock we caught a glimpse of the castle walls glittering in sunshine, a hopeful sign, and we set forward through the fog.” Her entry for 19 August, when they reached the “Top of Rigi,” makes no mention of fog.
Monday – Grey & rather foggy – mending stockings &c – Called with Mary at Mrs Scambler’s – (no rain) & Miss Dowling’s

Tuesday 11th
Wm went to Cockermouth Town 28 miles northwest of Rydal where WW and DW were born. This four-day trip was possibly connected to WW’s duties as Distributor of Stamps.
– Lovely sunshine comes out after grey morning. I to Fanny Wilson’s, Mrs Green’s, Mary Kirby’s Anne Green was the 40-year-old widow of William Green, the renowned Ambleside artist who had died in 1823. Mary Kirby may have been a former servant of the Wordsworths, judging from DW’s use of her first name. In a letter dated 27 December 1824, Dora appears to insinuate she would soon give birth out of wedlock, writing, “I am very sorry to say that poor Mary Kirby expects every day to be confined [–] this is one cause why Mr G has staid so long away [–] it is very lucky for Mary that he is away” ( WT MS WLL / Wordsworth, Dora / 1 / 6).

Wednesday 12th
Fine bright day – a little frosty … I walked – to Stone Man Likely Stone Arthur on the southwestern edge of Great Rigg (see GJ, 41, 201n).
&c on Loughrigg – Calling – Mrs Scambler to tea

Thursday 13th
Grey & mild – a little soft Rain. With Mary to Ambleside to Mrs Carr’s, Mrs Green’s, Mr Courtnay Philip Courtenay (1782–1842), barrister and political operative who often functioned as WW’s business agent (Letters, 4:121–22, 309).
– – – N.B. Since Monday, 1 Book of Dante per day

Friday 14th
Grey morning – soft rain[.] Walk with M. to Fox Ghyll: – very warm

Saturday 15th
All day rain. Wm. comes from Cockermouth

Sunday 16th
Very rainy. Church at Rydal – not cold.

Monday 17
Sunny morning, yet slight showers. Opened Mr E[lliott]’s windows. MW and DW were helping maintain Ivy Cottage between tenants. See MW’s report on 10 December: “I must now be off to close the windows – for the sun very, very soon leaves that gem of a Cottage & the frosty air will do it no good” ( WT MS WLL / Wordsworth, Mary / 1 / 64).
Called at P Kirby’s, Unidentified but presumably a relative of Mary Kirby (see note for 11 January).
Betty Dawsons. Old Woman fallen down stairs. After tea, beautifully bright. Miss J[ane] Dowling calls – D. at Mr North’s. Wm & I walked to Ambleside – gentle Rain then, – & a wet night. Letter from Sara better news SH was in Torquay helping care for Tom Monkhouse, who had momentarily taken a turn for the better (see note for 9 December).

Tuesday 18th
Very rainy – very dark – clears – windy & rather cold – – Walk with Julia & Mr R to John [Hester’s?] – Betty Dixon – handsome present Presumably a gift for Betty’s newborn, Diana (born 9 January).

Wednesday 19th
Very wet – not cold[.] Mr Carrs Dinner – to Ambleside alone in evening. Dark & Dirty … no rain –
Thursday 20th Wet morning – [ ] with Mr R to Mr Douglass’s[.] See note for 27 December. Windy – [snowy?] cold – At Mr Elliotts

Friday 21st
hail showers – rain showers. After dinner 2 hours on Terrace & at Mr E[lliott]’s. – Reading [Burke?] [ ] at [ ] [ ].

Saturday 22nd
Bright frosty morning. Walked with Mr R, by Fox Ghyll, to field above Mr Jackson’s During his tenure as Rector of Grasmere, Rev. Thomas Jackson, father of William Jackson, maintained a farm at Langdale, roughly three miles west of Rydal.
– Enchanting sunny view

Sunday 23rd
Very bright day at Rydal Church – With Miss E[liza] D[owling] after dinner to Ambleside.

Monday 24th
Gloomy frost. D at Mr Barbers. With Wm & Willy to Grasmere. Skates carried[.] Ice would not bear Snow at Night

Tuesday 25th
Deep snow – sunshine[,] frost. With John to Ambleside after dinner – called at Mr Carr’s.

Wednesday 26th
Snow again – William to Low Wood – I to Ambleside. Thaw & rain –.
Thursday 27th – – rain
Friday 28th – a fine day

Saturday 29th Rainy – I went to Kendal DW spent 29 January–15 February in Kendal with the Cooksons. In a 13 February letter, she wrote, “It was a fortnight yesterday since I came to Kendal, intending to stay but a week, however my kind Friends have been so unwilling to part with me that, having no particular object to call me home, I could not refuse” (Letters, 4:315).

Sunday 30th
Rainy. I not well. [ ] fine sky & clear frost – snow – & flood
--------------------
Remained at Kendal till

Tuesday 15th February – Mizzling rain in cart with Edwin The Cooksons’ youngest son. In her 13 February letter, she reported, “On Thursday, if weather be tolerable, Edwin is to go with me to Rydal. . . . He is a proud child at the thought of his journey. He says to me two or three times every day—‘I am going with you to Rydal!’ and talks of the Waterfalls and all that he is to see” (Letters, 4:316).
Wednesday 16th very fine & bright[,] warm
Thursday 17th – very wet. Mrs Luff came
Friday 18th – Lovely bright day
Saturday 19th – [Mild?] gloom. – I walked to Grasmere, round [brakes?] – wrote to Mrs Campbell & Mrs Elliott
Sunday 20th – Very bright & fine

Monday 21st – Lovely day – sunny. – Morris’s funeral Likely Wilson Morris, a local laborer who had done odd jobs for the Wordsworths as recently as November 1824 (Letters, 4:135, 168; WT MS WLL / Wordsworth, Mary / 1 / 63).
– wrote to Sara, Tillbroke, Miss Horrocks See note for 9 December 1824 entry.

Tuesday 22nd
Fine grey warm day – Walked with M. to Mrs [Tresway?], Mrs Harding’s, Both unidentified. The latter is possibly a misspelling of Mrs. Harden.
&c &c. Mary’s tooth drawn

Wednesday 23rd
Grey and cold. To Mr Carrs[,] Market, Mrs Luff’s alone

Thursday 24th – grey & cold but no wind – no rain since Thursday week – with Mary to Mrs Luffs & Fox Ghyll. Miss E[liza] D[owling] to dinner. Miss Knott, Mrs Huddleston Widowed aunt of the Wordsworths’ neighbor and landlord Lady Ann le Fleming, who had signaled she might not renew their lease at Rydal Mount so Mrs. Huddleston could live there.
– Met Wm & walk on Terrace ... not well soon to bed. Began Dante again
Friday 25th – Cold & grey – D & W to Calgarth – I to Mr Carr’s evening.
Saturday 26th – Snow – with Willy to Mrs Luff’s to tea
Sunday 27th – Sunshine. Snow falling in Flakes – – Star light & frost

Monday 28th
Very cold – snow again. Received the Tidings of our dear Friend T Monkhouse’s Death (on Saturday 26) at Clifton An extreme instance of DW’s almost clinical approach throughout much of RJ, belying how devastated she and the rest of the family were upon learning Tom Monkhouse had died at Clifton (near Bristol) at 41. Cf. the significantly more detailed, grief-ridden account DW sent Catherine Clarkson 12 days later (Letters, 4:324–26).

Tuesday 29th 1st March
Very cold. Snow covering hills & fields – walked to Fox Ghyll[.] Mrs L[uff] there

Wednesday 2nd
Thick snow – & snow late afternoon – walk on Terrace after dinner – again snow.

Thursday 3rd
Snow still falling – – walk on Terrace after dinner – – & now (12 o’clock) a thick covering – trees all white –.
Friday 4th More snow – and frosty clear night [–] walk on Terrace
Saturday 5th Lovely sunshine – dazzling hills – a Skin of Ice on Rydal Lake – long walk on Terrace
Sunday 6th – Cold Thaw & Rain

Monday 7th – Dull Thaw – Bright Evening. Mr Southey arrives. No snow at Keswick This weather report was courtesy of Southey, who was visiting from Keswick. MW noted on 25 February 1825 that he had delayed this planned visit by several weeks (Letters, 4:324).
– sate on Shore of Lake on Saturday – A rare instance in which DW works in a neglected detail from a previous day, as she generally scribbled any such omissions in the margins or between the lines of the entry for the day in question. This perhaps explains why DW or someone else has added a small question mark in the MS between “Shore” and “of.” “Sate” is an archaic form of “sat.”
Tuesday 8th – Slow dull Thaw
Wednesday 9th – Wet & dull[.] Still warm. John does not get off.

Thursday 10th – John goes DW reported on 13 February that “John Wordsworth will be going to Whitehaven before the end of this month, to stay till Easter” with William Jackson (Letters, 4:316).
– mild & dull – small, soft rain. The Carrs to dinner & Mr R.
Friday 11th – Mild pleasant day –
Saturday 12th – very fine – warm but coldish in the evening.
Sunday 13th – cold & rainy[.] Mrs Luff in afternoon. I drank tea with her

Monday 14th
Sunny morning – very cold – breakfasted with Mr J[ackson] – to Ambleside, about Hartley’s [will?] – grey cold afternoon. Walk in garden, on Terrace, Birkhagg field. Birk Hagg, a wood just north of Rydal. Mrs E[lliott]’s with D. Thermom. at freezing point. Thermometer readings appear regularly in later RJ notebooks, but this is the only such mention n Notebook 1.

Tuesday 15th
Bleak cold morning – snow [begins?].

Wednesday 16th
Still gloomy & cold, but pleasant walking[.] Mrs Harden’s with M. Mrs D Unidentified. She possibly meant “Miss D,” for Miss Dowling.
&c.

Thursday 17 – Bright & cold, very pleasant. Mr Barbers[.] New Road &c (all.) Willy’s accident. Apparently not a major injury, as this is the only reference to it in RJ or surviving letters. The entire family appears to have gone to Barber’s via the road that had just opened between Rydal and Grasmere. Comparing this new route (which remains the main thoroughfare today) and the old one, the Penny Magazine explained in June 1837, “Between Rydal and Grasmere the high road formerly ran winding among, and over a succession of knolls; and being half hidden in its serpentine course, afforded a series of exquisite views, without deforming this lovely valley. But the steepness of the hills was ill suited to the convenience of increasing traffic, and about twelve years ago a new road was made, which runs close along the lower end of Grasmere, and is fenced from it by a long, straight, odious stone wall, which offends the eye, and cuts the sweetest part of the landscape with its rectilinear deformity” (247).
Friday 18th – Snow – – Fox Ghyll[,] Terrace &c.
Saturday 19 – Bright, cold, busy in gardens.

Sunday 20th
Very Bright – Bishops Ladies Presumably the Watsons, the wife and daughters of the late Bishop of Llandaff.
at Chapel – walk after with W & M on new Road [–] beautiful Evening

Monday 21
Again fine – – not quite so sunny – & coldish air but very pleasant at Grasmere – [with?] Mrs Luff & [walk?]

Tuesday delightful in morning but Grey. At Grasmere with Mrs Luff & Aggy Although an Aggy Fisher and Aggy Black had worked for the Wordsworths, this was likely Agnes (“Aggy”) Ashburner, the hard-luck daughter of their former Grasmere neighbors Thomas and Peggy (see GJ, 41). MW reported in 1810, “Poor Aggy Ashburner is in the same situation as her sisters without having any hope of being made an honest woman of. . . . As to Aggy’s self she has I find little feeling about it—she is, which I never knew before, only a half-wit—poor Soul” ( WT MS WLMS / G / 1 / 2 / 7). In the intervening years, the Wordsworths had occasionally hired Aggy Ashburner to do odd jobs (Letters, :15, 79).
& walk with W & M.

Wednesday – very bright – air not warm – clear – delightful. Mrs Blakeney’s Sale. Since the recently widowed Margaret Edwards Blakeney (d. 1828) had just sold Fox Ghyll to Mrs. Luff, this multiday moving sale (see ensuing entry) disposed of furnishings from the home. DW writes of the appeal of such sales in the Green narrative, and De Quincey characterized them as highlights of the Westmorland social calendar, attracting rich and poor with the promise of free liquor (at the seller’s expense), occasional bargains, and chances to meet up with friends one rarely saw either because of “real distance” or the “virtual distance” that “results from a separation by difficult tracts of hilly country” (“Recollections of Grasmere,” 571).
I called at Miss Knott’s after Tea – good news. Presumably about an upturn in this chronically ill acquaintance’s health.
Lovely Crescent Moon & one Star at the Tip – exquisitely bright – Mr R. with me

Thursday 23rd 24
Colder air – very bright – Second Sale Mrs B[lakeney’]s. After Tea with Mary to Ambleside

Friday 25th
Dullish in the morning – Then very Bright – The Askews Family of Rev. Henry Askew of Greystoke, near Penrith (see Letters, 3:395).
call –. After dinner with Wm & M to Fox Ghyll. Met Mrs Luff to tea. [Hired?] her servant

Saturday 26th
Still very fine. Sauntered much – with Mr R after dinner to Fanny Wilson’s

Monday 28th – Very fine
Tuesday 29th – The same. Always cold in the mornings, & all-day Sun

– very fine evening – Walk on W. side of R[ydal] over Bridge & on new Road –

In the GJ for 2 June 1802, DW wrote, “This White Moss a place made for all kinds of beautiful works of art & nature, woods & valleys, fairy valleys & fairy Tairns, miniature mountains, alps above alps” (104).
– new Road home

Never [seemed?] sunshine. I with Sara & [W?] after dinner – White Moss

Wednesday 7th – The same &c.
Thursday 8th April D[itt]o

Thursday
A little Rain. Miss E[liza] D[owling] to tea. – –

Sunny & cold air

at Low Wood with Wm[.] Mild Rain – warm air

Very fine clear air [–] sunshine – – –

– Never all-day rain, & often delightful – half a sunny day or more – – –

to dinner – Rain in afternoon – – a little colder
Monday 2nd – Busy with Mrs Robinson &c &c – – still raining

Mrs Elliott – letter from Miss Horrocks. See note for 9 December 1824 entry.
Wednesday 4th – – Rain again, not heavy
Thursday 5th – Rain – air close – – Thunder on air

Violent thunder elsewhere [–] man killed on Lane
Saturday 7th – Very hot & close[.] Heavy showers in afternoon – fair morn – clears and we walk to Grasmere.

and after tea with Mrs Luff to Fox Ghy[ll]

Monday 9th – Very bright & clear – light air – Mr Pearson spending day – Ruins pulled down William Pearson (1780–1856) was a local antiquarian and admirer of WW’s poetry who had retired in his native Crosthwaite after a career as a Manchester banker (see Letters, 4:143). Since his correspondence with WW often touched on the region’s antiquities, he presumably had informed them about the pulling down of some nearby ruins.
– Mrs Luff at Whitehaven
All the week neglected Diary. Only one wet day. Books arranged &c &c
Sunday 15th May – very fine & bright – I went to Grasmere Church –
Monday 16th – grey & cool. Wm at Mrs Barlow’s
All the Rest of the week as fine as possible – bright Sun, but a little cold nights & mornings.

Friday (i.e. yesterday) May 20th spent with Wm. in going to Dun-mail Rays[,] he intending to go to Keswick – courage failed & came under Helm, &c – & visit Larch Grove Waterfall See Dora’s 21 May account (misdated 28 May in Letters) of how WW and DW “started yesterday but when they got to the top of the Raise [Dora’s] Father found himself ‘too weak’ to proceed. They spent the day in the Fields of Grasmere and reached home to a latish Tea” (4:351). After turning back at Dunmail Raise—the pass five miles northwest of Rydal that divides the valleys of Grasmere and Thirlmere—they would have passed under Helm Crag after a mile and a half and crossed Thomas King’s larch groves at The Hollens after another two miles.

Saturday 22nd 21
Busy at Ivy Cot, & with Letters – no reading this week – all bustle in two houses. – Carpets made &c &c. Beautiful Day. Miss Eliza Dowling & 6 young Ladies Cf. Dora’s corroborating report of being interrupted by “the arrival of a party of young ladies from Miss Dowling’s to tea – Julia [Myers] among them” (Letters, 4:352).

Sunday 22nd – Whitsunday The English equivalent of Pentecost, celebrated seven weeks after Easter.
– at Grasmere Church – no communicants but Robert Newton & myself A communicant is one who receives Holy Communion, or the sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, and Robert Newton was an old Grasmere innkeeper who appears several times in GJ (see 171n, 172n). DW’s report of the dismal turnout on this holy day lends credence to WW’s complaint earlier that year about how “in this Country . . . there is a sad want of zeal among Members” of the Established Church (Letters, 4:301).
– very fine day. This same day DW wrote in a letter to SH, “Spring-time is as delightful as the beginning, and Rydal more beautiful than ever. – Lilacs, Laburnums, and Roses all in full bloom” (Letters, 4:353).
Came home over Crags Nab Scar. – Mrs Harden &c at Rydal – seen at a distance

Monday 23rd
Very fine cleaning study. Mrs Cookson & 3 children, Mr C[ookson], Miss C[ookson] & Miss Jewsberry arrive – – various walks & [visiting?] after a stop to Dust & Labour among the Books – Much pleased with young Ladies – struck with Miss J. The Wordsworths were uniformly enchanted with the 25-year-old Jewsbury, a virtual stranger a month earlier who by summer’s end had become a family favorite and Dora’s “dearest friend” (LSH, 305; LDW, 22–28).
Rain in the night –

Tuesday 24th
Rather cloudy morning. Wm with the party at Stock Gill &c. Stock Ghyll Force, the waterfall just east of Ambleside.
M. & I putting up Books – washing carpet – threatening sky but no rain in afternoon – –

Wednesday 25th – Rainy morning, clears & we go to Langdale &c – Fair day. Mr Wilson met all Langdale The party followed a route WW had recommended in the 1822 edition of his Guide to the Lakes: “From Ambleside is a charming excursion, by Skelwith-fold and Colwith-force up Little Langdale, Blea Tarn, Dungeon-ghyll waterfall (if there be time) and down Great Langdale” (Description of the Scenery of the Lakes, 140). The inclusion of John Wilson (1785–1854, DNB), the eminent poet and critic and part-year resident of the Lakes, is somewhat surprising, as his once-close bond with the Wordsworths had been severely strained by his occasional rough handling of WW, Coleridge, and Southey—and myriad others—in Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine.
– Thompson & Family Possibly the proprietor of the gunpowder mill recently opened in the Langdale valley near Elterwater (see note for 11 June entry).
– no doors open at Dungeon Ghyll – dined in the Barn –. Likely at Millbeck Farm, a still-running eighteenth-century farm near Dungeon Ghyll Force. In her 1855 Complete Guide to the Lakes, Harriet Martineau advises, From [the Millbeck] farmhouse, where travellers can make a good meal of farmhouse fare, there is one thing to be done without doubt; – to visit Dungeon Ghyll. . . . Strangers who arrive untired generally go to the Ghyll while their ham and eggs are preparing” (146).
Fine day on the whole but with showers – Langdale pike seen through a veil of mist.

Thursday 26th May
Dined with the Party at Brummar Head. Poor Marys tooth drawn. I at Easedale Tarn Brimmer Head is on the outskirts of Grasmere on the way to Easedale Tarn, a picturesque pond two miles northwest of the village.
with Miss Cookson.

Friday 27th
At Troutbeck & Bowness. Town on the east shore of Windermere known partly for its ferry landing.
Cold air, very bright. Rain comes on, & Snow on the Mountains

Saturday May 28th
Mr Cookson dines here – young ones stay –. Fine moonlight – a little rain in afternoon

Sunday 29th
Air cold – fine morning. Rain in afternoon. Walk with Miss Cookson in Garden & on West Terrace. The “Far Terrace” at the western-most edge of the Rydal Mount property.
Fine moonlight night – moon on River.

Monday 30th
Mrs Smith WW and DW’s second cousin Mary Wordsworth Smith (1780–1867), the older sister of Dorothy Wordsworth Harrison. After her first husband, Capt. William Peake, died in combat in 1813, she married William Proctor Smith (Letters, 5:111n). In 1829 DW would note, “Mrs. Smith – She is Cousin Dorothy’s Sister, and like Dorothy in sweetness of temper etc., but has had the advantage of being much in good company, and has a stronger understanding” (Letters, 5:128).
arrives [–] finest day – I with Miss Cookson over hills & to Skelwyth Fold Skelwith Fold is four miles south of Rydal via the route they took, which had them ascending Loughrigg and then crossing Skelwith Bridge.
– Mrs S[mith] here on return.

Tuesday 31st
Ladies depart. Still very fine weat her, bright yet cool – With Mrs S[mith] & Miss C[ookson] to Ambleside. Ladies depart, Maria Jewsbury and the younger Elizabeth Cookson. much regretted – Party to Tea – various walks in fields &c. Mrs Harrison & party, to Tea – fine moonlight on Windermere

Wednesday June 1st
Very wet morning. Mrs Smith departs – all day rain[.] In evening, walked with W to Ambleside [–] very wet. Again began with Dante this morning

Thursday 2nd
Great flood – – Walk to Fox Ghyll – D[ora] to Langdale frightened a little by the high water. I walked to Ambleside after tea – – to seek lodgings for Miss D. Likely not one of the Dowlings (who already lived in Ambleside) but the Miss Dawson mentioned in the 22 and 27 June entries.

Friday 3rd
– Showery – went with M to Water head The northern tip of Windermere, just east of Brathay.
& Brathay. Met Wm Jackson – & Cousin D[orothy] &c. – Dora at Keswick – – Young party with Willy at Mr Robinson’s
