Very heavy showers. Called on Webbers, Apparently temporary residents of Rydal. Dora reported on 28 May 1825, “The Webbers’ Servants come on Monday and themselves on Wednesday. They must be Grandees for Mrs W said in a note to Margarite ‘I shall send over the Butler to order in coals etc.’” (Letters, 4:352).
Harrisons, Mrs Scambler,!--link--> [,] Mrs Carr,!--link--> – Wm J[ackson] to tea. Reading Excursion WW had begun revising the version of this book-length poem he had published in 1814. On 28 May, DW reported that WW and MW “have had a hard tug at the Excursion, and have gone through with it. [DW] begin[s] tomorrow to read it over” (Letters, 4:354).

Sunday June 5th
Rainy morning, clears in afternoon – Harrisons to Tea.

Monday – Cold but fair. D. rode to Kendal. Visiting the Cooksons, to whose children, especially Elizabeth, Dora was quite close.
Rainy evening – Tea at Col. Campbell’s

Tuesday 7th June
Mr Jackson dined here – unpacking Tea &c

Wednesday 8
Unpacking again. M busy with curtains. I at Ambleside. – Wet night [–] could not go to Miss Knotts

Thursday 9th
Very fine bright day. On Nab Scar See note for 2 December 1824 entry. with Miss Yarker. Likely Sarah Yarker (b. 1806), eldest daughter of Joseph Yarker, a customs collector from Ulverston (see note for 6 July entry).
Webbers[,] Mr Maltby, Likely either Rev. Edward Maltby (1770–1859, DNB), Mrs. Elliott’s only surviving brother, or one of his elder sons. The clergyman’s first wife, Mary, had just passed away in early May.
Mr B[enson] H[arrison], Miss Barlow, Mr Fraser Possibly Rev. Lionel Fraser (1807–1833), whom WW would later describe as a young friend of his from Peterhouse, Cambridge (Letters, 5:651). He may therefore have been staying with Tillbrooke, a fellow at Peterhouse.
to Tea.

Friday 10th
Fine warm day – [calls?] [Shirts?]. Bamford Robert W. Bamford, an inspector of schools near Durham who had taught John at the Grasmere school in 1812 (Letters, 3:7). WW had corresponded with Bamford as recently as 28 May (Letters, 4:349).
calls – Read Excursion See note for 4 June entry. out of doors[.] Letter from Mr R Henry Crabb Robinson (1775–1867, DNB), a close friend and regular correspondent with whom the Wordsworths explored the Continent in 1820 and hoped to take further excursions in the years ahead. DW responded to this letter from Robinson on 2 July (Letters, 4:372).
– D returning from Kendal. – Mrs Carr to tea. Supper with Mrs Luff

Saturday 11th
Lovely Day – with Wm. at Thompsons in Langdale Powder Mills According to
Industrial History of Cumbria, a gunpowder manufactory had opened near Elterwater in Langdale in 1824.
– Loughrigg
Sunday 12th – very hot [–] dined at Mr Robinsons. – Cold caught with heat in Langdale. To bed at 8. All this week, hot & splendid weather [all?]

Wednesday 15th
Now going to Kendal. On 2 July, DW mentioned having recently spent a week in Kendal with the ailing Miss Cookson (Letters, 4:372).
Very bright hot weather till Monday – then cold & dry after a little Rain on [Sunday?] night –

Friday – went with Mrs C[ookson] to Helsing & Levens Park – home by Canal The village of Helsington is seven miles south of the Cooksons’ home in Staveley, and Levens Hall is two miles farther south. The Lancaster-to-Kendal Canal by which they returned opened in 1819.
– Lovely night
Saturday – to Burton with James Burton-in-Kendal, on the southern border of Cumberland, is 16 miles south of Staveley. James was the Cooksons’ 21-year-old son.
Sunday to Hawes Bridge A picturesque crossing of the River Kent on the southern outskirts of Kendal (eight miles south of Staveley).

– and Tuesday the 21st of June –
came home with James – Cold & rather gloomy – walked thro’ my Lady’s Woods. The context suggests they had taken the liberty of passing through the woods of Rydal Hall, perhaps because Lady Ann le Fleming was not in residence (Letters, 4:370). Alternately, this could refer to Lady Wood, the field west of White Moss.

Wednesday 22nd
To Ambleside with James – cold & threatening Rain. Called on Miss Dawson, Unidentified but possibly a relative of Eliza Dawson Fletcher (see note for 28 June entry). DW’s referencing her as “Miss Dawson” rather than by her first name suggests she was not one of the laboring-class Dawsons whom the Wordsworths had employed.
– & Mrs Luff, & again at night at Ambleside. John arrived from Oxford disappointed of Sara – John and SH’s original plan to travel northward together was nixed by her needing to extend her stay with Tom and Mary Hutchinson (Letters, 4:374; SH, 305).

Thursday 23rd
Packet from Lancaster, all morning reading it Unclear but, given her describing reading it as a “job,” perhaps papers related to WW’s duties as Distributor of Stamps.
– & other jobs – Sunny but cold [–] sate under Crags – Frenchman Unidentified. called & the Watsons.

Friday 24th
Wrote various letters[.] D. was to have come from the Wood The Barlows’ home in Troutbeck. – a Rainy afternoon keeps her. It is very cold & dark – now at 9 o’clock – tired with letter-writing – Miss J, Sara, Miss Cookson, Mrs Johnson[,] Miss Barker &c – The first three listed correspondents are Maria Jewsbury, SH, and Miss Elizabeth Cookson. The fourth is likely Mrs. James Johnson of Kendal, of whom DW reported on 13 February, “A fortnight ago, poor Mrs J. on discovering that Mr. J had paid attentions not very delicate to her cook left the house with her 3 children” (Letters, 4:317). The last correspondent was Mary Barker, the old friend with whom DW made her “Excursion up Scafell Pike” in 1818 and who had since moved to France.
Saturday 25 – Letter from Miss B[arker]. Showery. D comes home – sunny gleams – –

Sunday 26th
Cold & showery. At Mrs Carrs to Tea, with Carlyles’ Perhaps the family of Robert Carlyle, an artist who based a number of prints and a five-canto romance (De Vaux; Or, the Heir of Gilsland [1817]) on his native Carlisle. In October 1825, MW forwarded some “Cumberland news” gleaned from a “Miss Carlysle” (LMW, 123), and in 1831 WW wrote a Miss Carlyle of Carlisle inquiring about lodging options there for Willy (Letters, 5:416).

Monday 27th
Fine day. Carlyles call & Miss Dawson. On Loughrigg Fell with W. Langdale pikes like a Tall mountain That is, WW and DW gazed westward from the top of Loughrigg at the Langdale Pikes.
– very fine – moon – but cloudy.

Tuesday 28th
Miss Carlyle to dinner [–] walk & Fletchers Possibly the Edinburgh philanthropist and early WW enthusiast Eliza Fletcher (1770–1858, DNB) and her attorney husband, Archibald Fletcher (1746–1828, DNB), who had met the Wordsworths through their common friends, the Hardens, in 1806. After her husband’s death, Mrs. Fletcher often holidayed in the Lakes before permanently moving to Thorney How in Grasmere in 1841 (Fletcher, Autobiography, 78, 89, 212–14, 221, 249).
– home with her at night. D poorly – brought [home?] medicine, & drowsy [–] clear sky[,] vapours rise

Wednesday 29
Still cold. Henry H Henry Hutchinson, the 55-year-old bachelor brother of MW and SH who settled on the Isle of Man after a career as a sailor.
arrives – showery – walk to Fox Ghyll, call on Miss King An old acquaintance of Mrs. Luff, dating to at least the early 1810s (Letters, 3:126).

Thursday 30th 31st
Mrs Luff & Miss K[ing] at Kendal. Fine day, but a shower or Two. – Tea at Mrs Campbell’s with Miss Dawson

Friday 1st July
Very fine day – Carlyles at Langdale. – Hay strewn & shorn See 4 July entry and other accounts of haymaking in LDW, 60; LMW, 92; and LSH, 240.

Saturday
Lovely day – Walk on Loughrigh with Henry H[utchinson] after dinner. Fright with the Cow Aggressive cows had been a perpetual source of fear since the GJ years. On 2 February 1802, DW confessed, “Every horned cow puts me in terror” (62); and on 10 June 1802, she reported Coleridge’s having “been attacked by a Cow” en route to Grasmere (108).
– very warm. Let fire out.

Sunday July 3rd
Fine day – not so warm – fine after Tea – Carlyles call [–] to Church –

Monday 4th
Fine day very busy – hay in – Made curtains for D’s bed. Mr Carr’s after Tea.

Tuesday 5th The first of four unusually detailed entries that chronicle DW’s four-day excursion to and from Kents Bank (23 miles south of Rydal on the southeast coast of the Cartmel Peninsula). The traveling party for the outward journey seems to have included DW, WW, MW, Mrs. Luff, Miss Dowling, and Miss Woodville, with at least MW and WW staying behind at Kents Bank for a family holiday.
– At ½ past 10 set off in Cart to Coniston Village eight miles southwest of Rydal at the northwest tip of Coniston Water. From there, as DW explains, the party hired a boat to sail down the lake.
– took up M. at Mrs Luff’s – Miss E[liza] Dowling & Miss Woodville Unidentified. Possibly a fellow teacher or a student from the Dowlings’ school.
in Road – cool, & rather dull – sun breaks out, fine lights on hills – . – I walked from Church Coniston. St. Andrew’s Church, completed in 1819 to replace Coniston’s sixteenth-century chapel.
The rest in cart – . – Met Mr H Henry Hutchinson met them in Coniston to guide them to his summer rental home on the lake.
in field, despairing of us & going to set off to Torver. Hamlet two and a half miles south of Coniston along Coniston Water’s western shore.
Dined in Boat – –. Middle of Lake least interesting – but in lower part, right shore very pleasing – varied with little rocks. Banks & wood – – Party waiting at Mr H’s summer house – Enchanting view up Lake – & backwards to the foot – – like a little peaceful soft lake – with verdant fields – farm house, hay makers. Standing on Mr H’s Rocky peninsula (cut into an Island) Hutchinson’s rental appears to have been on Fir’s Island (also known as Knott’s Island), midway along the eastern shore of Coniston Water. An island when the lake is high, it becomes a peninsula when the water recedes.
– thought of Trossachs – & compared the contrasts here to those between Lochs Katherine & Vennache Lochs Katrine and Venachar are both in the Trossachs, the mountainous region in central Scotland that DW first visited in 1803 and described in detail in Journal of My Second Tour of Scotland (1822).
– pleasant Ride to Ulverston. Thro’ firlets Apparently DW’s coinage. – woody peopled valley – River Crake – Iron foundry – Mr Penny’s house (Mr Machael’s – Penny Bridge). Ulverston is a major market town near the head of the Furness Peninsula. The nine-mile southward journey that DW’s party made that afternoon and evening from Fir’s Island to Ulverston followed the River Crake from the foot of Coniston Water through the Crake Valley, past the iron foundries at Nibthwaite and Penny Bridge, and on to Penny Bridge Hall. As DW’s shorthand account suggests, upon William Penny’s death in 1788, Penny Bridge Hall had descended to his son-in-law, James Machell (Bardsley, Chronicles of the Town, 118).
Noble oaks darkening sand – fine trees – rich meadows. Reach Lund between 7 & 8 – hospitality of old Mrs Harrison – 13 Gd children. Located on Ulverston’s eastern edge, “The Lund” was the hereditary estate of Benson Harrison, the new husband of DW’s cousin (see note for 31 May entry). Benson’s mother, “Old Mrs. Harrison,” was widowed in 1820 but apparently still presided at The Lund. With Benson being her only son, and possibly her only child, DW’s mention of “13 Gd. Children” may refer to godchildren rather than grandchildren.

Wednesday 6th On Day 2 of their trip, the party remained in the vicinity of Ulverston, confining their exploring to a six-mile round-trip excursion to Conishead Priory.
All walk to Priory grounds Conishead Priory, two and a half miles south of Ulverston near the Furness Peninsula’s eastern shore, was the site of a twelfth-century monastery, remnants of which had been razed in 1821 to make way for the modern buildings DW describes.
– – fine trees – long walks in grassy hollow. – Winter more agreeable here – Huntsmans Lodge Possibly Bardsea Hall (destroyed 1927), neighboring Conishead Priory to the south, which Lord Molyneux converted into a hunting lodge in the early eighteenth century.
– deep deep gloom – [a little?] shrouded – silver crescent horns – revealing form & notion of the dark bodies of the [ ] – unintelligible building – – Conservatory Chapel rich In 1830, Sir Edward Baines remarked that the new “conservatory of plants” Philip William Wyatt had designed at Conishead Priory “is tastefully constructed; its rich Gothic windows, with stained glass, and the ivy which covers the front, give it the appearance of a chapel” (Companion, 232).
– one part Flemish, but not so rich – another gothist – 2 fine Flemish Chimneys – on a wee wee Building out of taste – – Charming refreshment on shore – sit & [ ] – party with [ ] &c. Discover little Brook – travelling through the sands whose Birth place we had marked, & its girdle of water-plants – – Ulverston Church St. Mary’s, Ulverston’s ancient parish church. very [ ] – home thro hot Lanes –. Party in the evening – Wm and I to Ulverston with Mrs Ireland Probably Nancy Wordsworth Ireland, DW and WW’s cousin and Dorothy Harrison’s sister, who in the early 1810s had married a Rev. G. Ireland (Letters, 3:161).
and Miss Yarker –. Mrs Y. in bad health Likely referencing the family of Joseph Yarker (1764–1843), squire of Dykelands and royal customs collector for Ulverston. If so, the “Miss Yarker” here and in DW’s entry for 6 June would presumably be Joseph’s eldest daughter, Sarah Jane (b. 1806); “Mrs. Y” his wife, Margaret (b. 1786); and the “busy daughters” his unmarried younger daughters, Ann, Mary, and Margaret. Although none of the Yarkers are mentioned in the Wordsworths’ surviving letters, the Rydal Mount Visitors Book records the “Misses Yarker” of Ulverston visiting in 1836, 1838, and 1839 (DCMS 166, pp. 45, 55, 60, and 68).
– her busy daughters [sitting?] with her – Dismal visit to Mrs. B. Unidentified. Tears and lamentation – melancholy old age.

Thursday 7th DW’s intrepid Day 3 itinerary included a 10-mile coach ride along the Furness Peninsula’s eastern edge from Ulverston to Piel Island; a boat trip across the Leven estuary to the Cartmel Sands; a four-mile walk across the Cartmel Peninsula to Kents Bank; and, in the late afternoon and evening, an eight-mile hike northward from Kents Bank to Newby Bridge, where she lodged for the night.
– Rose at 6. Departed from Lund at ½ past 7. Waited with Mrs H[arrison] for Coach – Only one inside one out place. – Lovely morning – Lights on hills[,] clear air. – Mountains very grand – verdant spots below – – Wheels through deep water seeming not to move [–] silver streaky water, dull golden sands – – Piel Castle A fourteenth-century fortress on Piel Island built by the monks of Furness Abbey to protect the peninsula from attack by sea. For the Wordsworths, it had particular associations, as George Beaumont’s painting of the castle inspired the “Elegiac Stanzas” WW wrote upon the 1805 death of his and DW’s brother John.
– [Sailor?] in Coach – heard Crash & saw fall of part of ruin – – Land at Webster’s (Quarry Flat) Quarry Flat, an old sandstone mine along the Cartmel Sands and the ancestral home of the pioneering Cumbrian architects Francis Webster (1767–1827) and his son George (1797–1864,
DNB). There is no evidence the Wordsworths knew Francis, but they likely met George, the region’s most celebrated young architect, while he worked on Rydal Chapel (one of his first major commissions). For the Websters’ roots at Quarry Flat, see Rigge, “Harrington Tomb.”
– house unpromising – no view – closed up windows – very neat kitchen – kind woman – but saw at once in no state for us – Friendly talk. Cloth spread for new butter & churn milk – refused, & went on – – Lad called from gazing thro prospect glass A hand telescope. to guide us to Holker. Immediately northwest of Quarry Flat, this stately home and gardens has been in the Cavendish family since the late eighteenth century.
– – Delightful park, old place pretty, under hills – Large but not handsome white house. – Two noble sycamores in front – – & one other shorn like a Bush at top – very large – civil house-keeper When the owners were not in residence, housekeepers at grand homes were often permitted to offer tours to genteel visitors.
–. Finest pictures gone – – 1 Claude not fine left – – Sir Peter Lely’s Ladies – – & other portraits & pretty little Landscapes a few. Head of John Bunyan Much of Holker Hall’s impressive art collection, including the Bunyan portrait DW mentions, was lost in an 1871 fire. Among the rescued works were Sir Peter Lely’s Lady Cleveland in Mourning and two of the family’s four paintings by Claude Lorraine (or “Claudes”). See Stockdale, Annales Caermoelenses, 424–32.
– – Thence to Cark – Dusty hot vulgar Village – then Flukborough the [inn?] (called at Inn arranged about water.) In the manuscript, this aside comes in a footnote, the only such note in Notebook 1 (see fig. 2). Parentheses are added here for readability.
– – on to Allisthwaite From Holker Hall, the party traveled one and a half miles south through the village of Cark and on to the inn at Flookburgh. From there they headed east for three miles to Allithwaite.
in pretty dell – Ivied wall – 2 old halls, one with a turret or burl. The two halls are Boarbank Hall and Wraysholme Tower, the latter a fifteenth-century fortress with multiple turrets. A burl is a bump or protuberance.
Climb hill to [Mortal Man?] – – – Thence on to Kents Bank but turn aside, to prospect hill – Turret – descend to Kents Bank – Charming hill. – Flowers turf – sheep [–] stones worn away – – through little orchard – civil men – Call at Inn – Taken lodgings. The parodic Kent’s Bank Mercury produced by Dora and Jewsbury indicates that, while the Wordsworths stayed in the coastal cottage of their acquaintance William Ashburner, others in their party were “compelled to take up their lodgings in the adjoining Hotel” (WLMS A / Jewsbury, Maria Jane / 52).
Dine – – On to Grange – charming Italian scenery – pretty houses[,] gardens. Elder Bushes – – Liddle pretty village in dell. The village of Grange-over-Sands is two miles up the coast from Kents Bank. From there, Lindale is two miles inland to the north.
Discovered chapel – – embosomed in Trees, but before this a fine view – – from hill, over sands, & Castle head A Georgian-style country house built in 1778 for the industrialist John Wilkinson.
discovered on plain – woody mount, pleasure paths. Think of Belagio. Bellagio, the picturesque Italian resort on Lake Como, which DW saw in 1820.
A little way from Liddle discover well on side of road –. Entrance arched, rather lintelled over with old ash stem – – Roof arched with stone – green with moss ... Ivy with Adder’s Tongue fern A variety of fern so named because its stalk resembles a snake’s tongue. It survives as an underground rhizome nine months of the year, appearing above the surface only during the summer.
& Geranium – descend [by?] steps – 8 – broken with age – 3 niches. What [gent?] has this been dedicated – Inquire of woman – – never noticed it – of Boys – Oh yes! – What do they call it[,] what name has it[?] Oh! it’s Dicky [Greyson?] well .... Why so? – Perhaps he [named?] it. Does he live there now? Nay he’s sellt up. It must be very auld. Ay, says Boy I remember it a long time – (he not more than 16) – Companion Rolling in Dust like an ass of the desart – [On?] & [ ] [ ] – On through woody valley; [hut?] on side of hill – – Still woody country – Parts very populous. Farm houses picturesque[.] Reach Newby Bridge about 8. After Tea strolled up & down River – the dark figure of an Angler standing on the slippery slope of the Weir A barrier or dam in a river. – that with its whiteness brought out the lower part of the man’s figure – Could not see the pipe in his mouth, but discovered that he was smoking, by a thin small volume of vapour in the air, which was faintly reflected in the smooth water above the Weir – Soon to bed & paid Bill intending to rise early. – Charge for both 3/6 – & very much obliged for a Shilling over –

figure.figDesc: Figure 2: Portion of the 7 July 1825 entry in DCMS 104.1

div.p:
Friday July 8th Day 4 began with a seven-mile early morning hike from Newby Bridge to Far Sawrey along Windermere’s western shore. From there DW took the Windermere ferry to Bowness, walked two and a half miles to Troutbeck for breakfast with the Barlows, and then traveled five miles on foot to arrive at Rydal Mount in the late afternoon. She never specifies whether she was accompanied by others on this return leg of the trip.
A very fine morning –. Rose at ½ past 4 – off at 5 minutes past 5 – Returned to seek W’s glove – Shady cool lane – – House to Right (supposed Mr Townley’s) a naked-yellow Front, Naked as in bare or devoid of shrubbery. DW seems to be looking across the narrow southern tip of Windermere toward Town Head, the recently renovated estate of William Townley, High Sheriff of Lancashire.
& hugged in on each side, by choked up plantations Apparently, a sidelong allusion to the massive larch plantation the late Richard Watson had established above Town Head on Gummer’s How. Since 1810, WW had vehemently denounced such “vegetable manufactories” in successive editions of his Guide to the Lakes.
– pretty green prospect – white church on the hill – among coppice woods – – – Stock Park & Mr Lowthwaites DW slightly misremembers both names. In his Tourist’s New Guide, William Green clarifies that Stott (not Stock) Park was “late the seat of George Braithwaite, Esq., but now the residence of his sisters” (1:197).
– Low under Woods … Fine & numerous yew trees on the steeps near Stock Park – Low Graithwaite\ Green lists “Abraham Rawlinson, Esq., a minor” as the owner of Low Graithwaite, noting that Graithwaite is where “the ferry and Hawkshead roads unite” (1:197).
in style of Rydal Mount. Fine Larches – & other fine trees. But all hereabouts buried & chill with woods & Mr Sands’s worst of all – Spoiled plantations. Miles Sandys, then the squire of High Graithwaite, had followed Watson’s lead in investing in larch plantations on his property near Windermere. DW’s complaint about this specific plantation echoes a remark WW inserted into his Guide to the Lakes in 1822 about how “the view from the Pleasure-house of the Station near the [Windermere] Ferry has suffered much from Larch plantations” (138).
Dull traveling compared with the cottaged & farm-housed valley last night. Many woods, all belonging to Gentlemen. Noble view after Graithwaite – Storrs’ Clock strikes 7 From the opposite shore of Windermere, DW appears to have heard the bell of St. Martin’s, the parish church just north of Storrs Hall.
– – Ferried over Lake. When I observed to Boatsman that all the Land was divided among the Gentry, & that it was more chearful, when scattered over with houses, he replied “Aye it is more christian-like – Its like a wilderness” – “a genteel wilderness” says Wm –. Presumably a remark from conversation, as this phrase does not appear in WW’s published works.
At Mrs Barlow’s at 10 [–] Breakfast & Luncheon While breakfast would have been a full meal, luncheon was more of a light repast a few hours before the mid-afternoon dinner.
– home at 4 with Miss B[arlow] – – wrote to Miss J[ewsbury], to Mary –

Saturday – 9th July.
Very hot – & bright. Wrote to Mrs Coleridge – – Sought speakings Passages from literary texts that one memorized or recited.
two hours – – –. Read Madam Genlis. First published in English translation in early 1825, Memoirs of the Countess de Genlis attracted a wide English readership with its vivid accounts of the atrocities of the French Revolution and the aristocratic debauchery that preceded it. Writing H. C. Robinson on 2 July, DW exuded, “I am deep in Madame de Genlis’s life – a hundred times more entertaining than the best of our now-a-days novels – and how much more surprizing!” (Letters, 4:375).
Made wine –. Cf. entries from 3, 4, and 10 December 1824.
Wm at Tea at Mr Webber’s. See note for 4 June. They called in morning.

Sunday 10th – Very hot. Thunder storm in church & flood. – Barlows & Miss Dawson See note for 22 June. to dinner. Mr Wilkinson & mother Most likely “Lakers” who called while traveling through the region, not the abolitionist Thomas Wilkinson(who was too old to have a living mother) or the artist Joseph Wilkinson (who fell out of contact with WW after 1810).
to Tea & all night. Dora very poorly.

Monday 11th
Fine day, but still thundery. To Ambleside with Wilkinsons – Odd jobs for D &c. all day, & at night to Ambleside again[.] Tea with Mrs Carr – consult about D – wrote letters

Tuesday 12th
Rose at 4. John & D. go to Ulverston. Warm, breezy morning – – cloudy afternoon, threatening of Thunder [–] wrote to Sara, Mrs Cookson, Mary MW had stayed behind at Kents Bank for a family holiday after arriving there with DW on 7 July.
–. Allan Bank Home of the Campbells. to Tea. Reached home at ¼ before 11. Good news of Dora –.

Wednesday 13th
All day heavy rain. Wm at Low Wood – [Such?] [ ] – Mr Gould Unidentified. – I walked to Ambleside – Stifled with heat

Thursday 14th
Rainy morning – Clears up – very fine, but sultry[.] Barlows & Mr Bailey Likely a brother of Frances Bayley Barlow (see Axon, Family of Bayley, 47–48).
to Tea

Friday 15th July –
Fine morning – sunshine but sultry – cloudy afternoon, heavy rain – damage in walks repaired

Saturday 16th
Fine morning – but sultry. Rainy afternoon – – clears beautifully. Lovely Evening. Walk with Wm. on Terrace – Ruby Lights on Lake –

Sunday 17th
Very hot – Barlows – & [pews?] quite full – Mrs Maltby See note for 9 June. Since the future Bishop Maltby had just lost his wife, this may have been a daughter-in-law.
to tea [–] loveliest evening ever seen –

Monday 18th clear and intensely hot – packing For the following day’s trip to Kents Bank. – making Jelly – &c &c. Mrs de Quincey at night Since their lease had ended at Fox Ghyll a few months earlier, Margaret De Quincey and her children had lived with her father at Nab Cottage in Rydal. This entry seems to refute Gittings and Manton’s contention that DW unfeelingly ignored Thomas De Quincey’s 16 July plea to attend to his depressed and possibly suicidal wife until he could return from London (241, 246).

Tuesday 19th Despite having just made the round-trip journey to Kents Bank less than two weeks earlier, DW chose to accompany WW, Dora, and Willy on the start of their six-week summer holiday. At various times the family would be joined by Maria Jewsbury, the Southeys, the Barlows, SH, and several of the Kendal Cooksons. John and DW remained behind at Rydal Mount. Dora and Jewsbury offered a lively account of this holiday in their parodic Kent’s Bank Mercury (WLMS A / Jewsbury, Maria Jane / 52).
– Up, 10 minutes before 4 – off to Kents Bank before 5 – wet meadows, clear air, very hot – At Kents Bank ½ past one –. Dora improved – all but me bathe – unpack, arrange &c &c. To bed after Dinner. Ladies arrive from Lancaster to tea. Maria Jewsbury among them. Unclear who the others might be.
Climb hill. Mountains hazy – ruffling Breeze – On return heard of a thunder storm at Ambleside & Rydal Several days later, signaling that she wrote this entry after returning to Rydal.
– – not a Drop of rain with us at K[ents] B[ank]

Wednesday 20th – very hot – I depart at ½ past 5. – changes to cold – dull and grey – [ ] road. Mrs Barlows past 10, home at 12 By this account, DW made the 23-mile trip from Kents Bank to Rydal in six and a half hours (including, it seems, a brief visit with the Barlows in Troutbeck).

Thursday 21st
Agreeable coolness. Learned at Mrs Barlows of heavy thunder shower here on Tuesday. Boiling preserves – letter-writing &c all day. Called at Mrs Luff’s, Mrs R[obinson’]s – John at Mrs Harden’s Dance. Invitation to Wood The Wood, home of the Barlows. before breakfast. Mr Jackson from Harrowgate Harrogate, the spa town north of Leeds.

Friday 22nd
Still cool, & clear [–] busy all day – letters, Jelly, & after dinner with Barlows to Grasmere, & walk with John to Ambleside

Saturday 23rd
Jelly – Beautiful day – Rush-bearing The old Westmoreland tradition, still practiced today, of covering church floors with rushes in July. In his Ecclesiastical Sonnets, WW celebrated this practice in the poem Rural Ceremony (No. XXII) (Sonnets, 425n).
– – various letters[.] Mr Yates Unidentified. called.

Sunday 24th
Cool pew – singers removed Obscure but possibly connected to the rush-bearing rites.
–. No company but Mrs Luff in afternoon, & J. & I drank tea with her –. Catechism Likely studying the catechism, or lessons preparatory to confirmation, included in the Anglican Book of Common Prayer.
&c., & bed at ½ past 10[.] Miss J[ewsbury]’s Gazette Presumably reading recent poems by Maria Jewsbury published in the Manchester Gazette.
– Mrs Yates calls again.

Monday 25th
Same clear delightful heat. John to Kents Bank. Tea with Miss Dawson [–] walk up Stock-gill The ravine and waterfall on the edge of Ambleside. – beauteous Evening. John returns To make the 45-mile round-trip journey to and from Kents Bank in a single day, John must have traveled by horse.

Tuesday 26th
John off to Keswick – finished preserves – wrote to Mary & Mrs C. Likely Mrs. Cookson but possibly Sarah Coleridge.
Letters from Sara. Mr Wm Jackson calls – Campbells – Miss Knott – go with her past Lords’ Oak. A renowned oak growing out of a wall along the road between Rydal and Ambleside.
Meet Robinsons, walk with them. Christening fixed. DW’s wording seems to connect this christening to the Robinsons, but their newborn twins, Charles and Charlotte, had already been christened in Grasmere on 5 January 1825. This and the 2 August entry may therefore allude to the rechristening of Henry Wilkinson Cookson (1810–1876, DNB), Thomas and Elizabeth’s sixth son. Henry had been baptized a Unitarian at birth but was rechristened an Anglican on 29 August 1825, presumably to qualify for Cambridge (which until Catholic Emancipation in 1829 admitted only Anglicans).
Loveliest of nights moonlight. Called on Mrs Luff in her Bed-room – past 10

Wednesday 27th
Danl. Green called Rev. Daniel Green (1798–1829), son of John and Molly Green of Grasmere, had recently graduated from Cambridge and taken clerical orders (Letters, 4:218n6).
– Mr Waterhouse & Mr Hoyle. Mr. Waterhouse is unidentified; Mr. Hoyle was possibly Rev. Charles Hoyle (1773–1848), vicar of Overton, Wiltshire, and author of the Biblical epics Moses Viewing the Promised Land (1804) and Exodus: An Epic Poem (1807).
Thus occupied & tying preserves Tying down a jar’s lid was a common method for sealing preserves.
all the Morning – John from K[eswick], with Barlows to Tea. – Out of doors – Lovely night [–] Tillbroke arrives With Ivy Cottage temporarily vacant after the Elliotts’ departure, Tillbrooke stayed in his own quarters on this trip. SH reported on 7 August that “Till & his fellow Tutor are at the Ivy Cottage with which he is charmed” (WT MS WLL / Hutchinson, Sara / 2 / 110a).

Thursday 28th – Rose at 6 – Mrs Carr called [–] Again the same delightful weather – Col Campbell with party – after call on Tillbroke – Miss Dawson to Tea. Tillbroke & Gentlemen, & Mrs Luff. Walk to Ambleside with Miss D[awson][.] Supper at Mr R[obinson]’s –. Moonlight too warm & pleasant to go to Bed.

Friday 29th
Shelled pease while Mary was cleaning – Lloyd Likely Charles Lloyd (1775–1839,
DNB), the poet and philanthropist who, prior to his mental breakdown in 1813, lived with his wife and eight children at Old Brathay near Ambleside. After a brief period in Keswick (LMW, 84), he spent his final years in France. Once part of the Wordsworths’ broader social circle—especially after his sister, Priscilla (1781–1815), married WW and DW’s brother, Christopher—Lloyd rarely interacted with them after the mid-1810s.
called – Tea out of doors with John. Walked to Mrs Luffs with Tillbrook & John. Most beautiful night
Sat. 30th –
Sund. 31st – The month closes [ ] the same fine weather. Very hot. Mrs Luff to Tea – various visitors, letters

Monday 1st
Still very hot:

Tuesday 2nd
Christening-day See note for 26 July entry. [–] fine [–] showers in morning. Fine afternoon.
Wednesday 3rd – Heavy rain.
Thursday 4 Showery

Friday 5th – The same – Sara H. arrives Returning to Rydal after an absence of over two years, SH wrote on 7 August, “This place is more beautiful than ever, but there is great want of the axe & pruning knife. The Trees have grown so much that we are quite shut out from any prospect” (WT MS WLL / Hutchinson, Sara / 2 / 110a).
– & Mr Parrin. Likely Robert Perrin, editor of the Carlisle Patriot (see Letters, 4:460, 469).
John goes to the Balloon. On 5 August, thousands flocked to Kendal Castle for a highly anticipated balloon launch by Charles Green, England’s foremost aeronaut. By noon, though, the flight had been canceled because of a slight wind, leading the WG to decry the entire event as a hoax (The Balloon!!!, 6 August 1825).

Friday, October 7th
Since the day of Sara Hutchinson’s arrival (August 5th), I have not written a word. – Weather was then broken. – Mrs Hutchinson Mary Hutchinson, wife of MW and SH’s brother Tom, who was traveling to recover her health and to be away from Brinsop during a major renovation. She would spend a month at Rydal before going with MW to Harrogate, the spa town near Leeds (Letters, 4:392).
and the party came from Kent’s Bank on Monday, 15th August – A few days of cold weather. Afterwards very fine & very hot – for some time – Consecration &c &c Eight months after its opening (see 25 December 1824 entry), the chapel of St. Mary in Rydal was consecrated on 27 August by the Bishop of Chester. Anticipating this major event, SH wrote on 7 August, “We are to have grand doings at the consecration on the 27th” (WT MS WLL / Hutchinson, Sara / 2 / 110a). SH provided additional details on both the consecration and Sir Walter Scott’s visit (see following note) in her sketch diary for early August (WT MS WLMS H / 1 / 6 / 2).
– Mr Canning[,] Sir Walter Scott In late August, John Bolton, a wealthy Liverpool businessman who had retired to Storrs, his 1,000-acre estate along Windermere, organized a gala honoring the former prime minister and conservative icon George Canning. Among the Tory luminaries who attended were the Scottish writers Walter Scott, John Wilson, and John Gibson Lockhart (see Barker, 579). In a 22–31 August letter to Maria Jewsbury, Dora gave a wickedly candid report of the breakfast the Wordsworths hosted for these writers at Rydal Mount (LDW, 23–25).
– I went to Hallsteads Home of the Marshalls. DW spent a week there in September (Letters, 4:392).
– returned to consecration with C. Marshall Cordelia, the Marshalls’ 22-year-old daughter, who was close to both DW and Dora.
… – Broken weather since[.] Mary W. went to Harrowgate with Mrs H[utchinson] … Many fine days, but mostly damp oppressive heat – a plague of catterpillars in gardens.

Now (October 7th) It will be a month on Monday since M.W. went to H[arrogate]. They are all now on their way southward – Mrs Luff to London, John to Oxf., the rest to Coleorton. After hosting visitors throughout the summer, the Wordsworths scattered in the fall. John returned to Oxford, and MW and Mrs. Hutchinson met up with SH and WW at the Beaumonts’ Leicestershire estate, Coleorton. DW wrote on 18 October, “It will be fortnight on Thursday since Dora and Willy and I were left alone—thoroughly alone—for Mrs Luff accompanied [WW, MW, and SH] to Manchester on her way to London, summoned thither by the dangerous illness of Lady Farquhar” (Letters, 4:392). Lady Maria Farquhar and her husband, Sir Robert Townsend Farquhar (1776–1830, DNB) had become friends with Mrs. Luff in Mauritius, where he served as the colonial governor.
Miss Honeyman Mary Honeyman (1775–1851) was the unmarried daughter of a Presbyterian minister from Penrith who may have known DW in connection with her parents having taken in the orphaned Sarah Green in 1808 (Letters, 4:392n3; Cumberland Pacquet, 14 January 1851, 3). Regarding the warm friendship that developed during this visit, DW wrote on 18 October, “Miss Honeyman has been staying with us a fortnight – very happy – She has had a whole summer of quiet rambling, and returns with pleasure to her winter duties at Penrith. She has a small house there – has a comfortable independence of her own making, and is able thoroughly to enjoy it. Her good religious and moral principles, and her great desire to be useful provide her with constant enjoyment, so she is not like one put out of place by relinquishing the labours of her Business. Dora and I find her an excellent companion” (Letters, 4:392–93).
has been here a week.

[October 6th]
The party off yesterday at 4 o’clock – – a little rain, but pleasant day, & not so very hot. – John Cookson & Miss Fothergill John was the 21-year-old son of the Kendal Cooksons. Miss Fothergill is unidentified.
met Miss H[oneyman] & me on road to Ambleside, turned back. Waterfalls – Luncheon &c &c – & off before dinner. – Went down to visit Harrison’s wife Perhaps Catherine Harrison, the wife of WW’s old friend Anthony (see note for 17 December), as DW consistently refers to her cousin Dorothy Harrison as “Mrs. Harrison.”
& J Carter John Carter (1797–1863), WW’s clerk from 1813 until the poet’s death in 1850.
& Robinsons before Tea. Then set to at the Hardens’, by fire side.

October 7th
Soft grey morning – hopeful for Langdale but heavy rain set in – & now (at 10 o’clock) is falling pell-mell. – Clears in the afternoon, brisk wind & sunshine. Miss H[oneyman] & I walked to Grasmere – – called at Mr Barbers, M Fishers, Likely Mary Dawson Fisher, the Wordsworths’ former maid who had married John Fisher in 1817 after having born him at least one child (GJ, 162, 257; WT MS WLMS 7 / 163).
Mrs De Q’s &c. Comet at night[.] Jos & Willy quarrel – Jos off Possibly either the Hardens’ 20-year-old son or the Joseph mentioned in DW’s entry for 7 December 1824.

8th
Fine morning – at 7 – packed up for Windermere. Rain comes on – & continues (heavy) all day. Tom Robinson Lt. Tom Robinson became such a fixture at Rydal that autumn that word of his designs on Dora soon reached SH at Coleorton. In a gossipy 3 November letter, SH seems to reference neither party having a fortune when she quips, “Tom Robinson finds Rydal so attractive that he is a poor support to his Mother – This is news for Mary, but she need not fear taxation, on the part of the Lady – Dora I mean – & the youth also is too wise. He sees enough of love in a Cottage at the foot of the hill” (WT MS WLMS H / 1 / 6 / 5).
arrives from [ ] – I go with him to tea below – still rains – home [with me?] to supper. Murray drowned Obscure but possibly pertains to the publisher John Murray. While he most certainly hadn’t drowned, his name had become a byword at Rydal Mount in 1825 for his supposedly high-handed treatment of WW (Letters, 4:397).

Sunday 9th
T[om] R[obinson] to breakfast[.] Letter from Miss Jewsbury – The party left Marshalls’ on Tuesday morning. – Heavy rain comes on at Church – continuous & in afternoon I walked to Scandale Bridge Bridge over Scandale Beck, midway between Rydal and Ambleside.
with Mrs Carr[,] Miss H[oneyman], T. R & D. [gone?] to waterfall Likely Stock Ghyll Force outside Ambleside.

Monday 10th
Heavy rain, in afternoon. Mr R[obinson] & Leonard E Leonard Edmunds, the 23-year-old son of the Ambleside solicitor and political operative John Edmunds and, given DW’s use of his first name, likely an old friend of the Wordsworth children. In 1833 he would receive a royal appointment as Clerk of the Patents (Carlisle Journal, 2 September 1833, 2).
to dinner. I at Ambleside in morning with Miss H[oneyman] – wrote to Mr T. & Mrs C about house. She presumably was informing Tillbrooke and Mrs. Cookson that the Wordsworths may need to vacate Rydal Mount in the months ahead (see note for 24 February entry).
[Rise?] in Weather glass This seemingly suggests that, besides the thermometer referenced elsewhere in RJ, the Wordsworths owned a weather glass (or storm glass). Invented ca. 1780, these fashionable (and generally unreliable) devices consisted of a slender glass tube filled with a chemical mixture that supposedly crystalized as a storm approached (see McConnell and Collins, “Will the True Originator”).
– wrote Mrs Marshall

Tuesday 11th
Very fine afternoon. Mr F. Fleming Rev. Fletcher Fleming of Rydal Chapel. & Miss Dawson call. Walk with Miss H[oneyman] to Grasmere – Carters See note for 7 October. & Mr Fox Unidentified. at Mr Barbers – cross water.

Wednesday 12th This and the ensuing three entries describe DW’s second multiday journey to Coniston in the past few months, albeit in much less detail than her earlier entries from early July.
In cart to Coniston See note for 5 July. with Miss H[oneyman] – clear cool air – hazy mountains yet sunshine below. – Heavy shower at night.

Thursday 12th DW mistakenly dates consecutive entries the 12th. Her dating would get back on track on Saturday, 15 October.
Lovely morning – out on Lake. Coniston Water. – D. & T[om] R[obinson] arrive to dinner. We depart after. Infernal Regions of Backbarrow – Raging River – altogether awful. Immense illuminated Holes [–] White-water torrents and weir-holes in the River Leven at Backbarrow, a village in south-central Cumbria, were frequently cited instances of the sublime (or, as DW puts it here, the “awful”). In Antiquities of Furness, Thomas West describes how the Leven “falls with great rapidity for the space of two miles, dashing its waters against the rugged rocks, which oppose its course, through Backbarrow, forming several cascades” (36).
Supper & bed at Newby Bridge In the approximately four hours between dinner and the 7:00 p.m. mid-October sunset, the party covered nearly 15 miles: 13 from Coniston and Backbarrow and another mile and a half to Newby Bridge. It seems likely, then, that the first leg of their itinerary, wherein they traversed the length of Coniston Water, was made by boat.

Friday 13th – Very fine morning. – Rain comes on – Stormy Fury – foolish Sail-Boat. Hat lost – – Rainy journey – no views at Station – very fine after Bowness. From Newby Bridge, they seem to have rather ill-advisedly (as DW would have it) hired a boat to take them roughly eight miles up Windermere’s western shore to the viewing station at Claife Heights, which West had popularized in his 1778 Guide to the Lakes. From there, they took the ferry to Bowness, on Windermere’s eastern shore.

Saturday 15th Bright morning – showers … – & showery afternoon – prepare to go to Low Wood – meet the Mackintoshes An exhausted DW reported on 18 October that the Scottish barrister and politician Sir James Mackintosh (1765–1832) and his daughter had been the “last of [their] Lakers” to visit during “the most bustling summer ever remembered.” Having known him since at least 1812, she wrote, “Sir James looks wonderfully well, considering the wearing life he has led—politics—law—India—house of Commons wrangling!” (Letters, 4:392–93; see also 3:45, 4:388).
at Waterfall Stock Ghyll Force near Ambleside. –

Sunday 16th
Showery – but pleasant. Mackintoshes to Luncheon [–] T. Robinson [–] Mr Barber to Tea.

Monday 17th
Cold & showery – to Mrs Luffs – wrote to Coleorton Home of the Beaumonts, where WW and MW were currently staying.
– & Mrs L. Mary Laing, who, after visiting Rydal in 1822 with her brother, the antiquarian David Laing, had corresponded regularly with DW (Letters, 4:154n, 233, 238, 394).
The Robinsons to Tea and Cards

Tuesday 18th
Very rainy [–] wrote to Mrs Clarkson Her old friend and regular correspondent Catherine Clarkson (see Letters, 4:391–94).
... Miss H[oneyman] left us in the Evening. Stormy walk – and all to Tea at Mr Robinsons [–] very heavy rain at night

Wednesday 19
Dora was to have gone to Coniston – no horse for Mr R – all walked to Ambleside. Julia to dinner – very bright & cold but tremendous rain at night[.] Julia stays. Anne poorly unknown to us Their housemaid Anne Harrison.

Thursday 20th
Very cold – very clear – mountains snowy. Fern bright – smooth-topped white hills – very like alps – green treey ridge below. Dora & T[om] R[obinson] to Coniston. Before dinner I called on Mr de Q The first appearance in RJ of Thomas De Quincey, who, after an 18-month absence, had rejoined his family at his father-in-law’s farm near Rydal.
... Mrs Barlow & Miss Walker Perhaps a relative or friend staying with the Barlows at The Wood, as in July 1826 Dora alluded to “two Mr Walkers” being with them in Troutbeck (LDW, 33–34). Another possibility is Hannah Walker, whom DW had met in Eusemere a few weeks earlier and afterward described as “a perfect specimen of beauty in old age” (Letters, 4:392).
on returning dined with us, & Miss Honeyman – Miss Nelson Unidentified. to tea – I went to Ambleside – [poor?] Mr Ladyman Presumably Joseph Ladyman, proprietor of the Salutation Inn below Stock Gill in Ambleside. He had possibly fallen upon financial hardship, as the inn would be put up for lease in 1828 (Lancaster Gazette, 6 December 1828, p. 2).
– .... Clear moonlight night [–] read Life of Charles Likely Dr. John Lingard’s new biography of Charles I, which appeared as the tenth volume of his monumental History of England from the First Invasion by the Romans (London: Mawman, 1825).
– Willy busy for his journey Apparently to join Dora and Tom Robinson at Coniston (as the next entry suggests).

Friday 21st
Willy off to Coniston before breakfast – Cold and clear. The Southeys arrive in chaise. The teenage Southey girls, Bertha and Kate, would stay at Rydal until 11 November.
Stormy and rain comes on[.] Mary came home Unclear to which Mary she refers, as MW would not return from Coleorton for another four weeks (see 17 November entry).

Saturday 22nd
A lovely bright day – warm – in sun – clear air[.] Walk with Southeys to Ambleside – Mr Carr visits Anne. Visiting their ailing servant Anne (see 19 October) in his capacity as a physician.
Miss Honeyman to dinner & Tea. After leaving Rydal Mount on 18 October, Miss Honeyman apparently stayed with others in the vicinity before her return to Penrith.

Sunday 23rd mild Rain. Mr Barber comes at dinner time. Walk with him after Church. Splendid sky – purple & ruby hues, in sky & lake – Emerald Isle The context suggests she is referring not to Ireland but to the greenness of one of the four small islands in Rydal Water.
[–] Gipsies on hill – Gypsy sightings were increasingly rare in rural England during this period, in part because of restrictive measures like the Vagrancy Act of 1824 (Cressy, Gypsies, 148–51). WW’s 1807 poem “Gypsies” was less than sympathetic toward these “wild outcasts of society,” but DW reported to William Pearson in 1830 that “every member of this family” had been captivated by accounts he had gathered from his “vagrant neighbours” (Letters, 5:220).

Monday 22nd 23
Fine Day – walked to Ambleside – –

Tuesday 23rd 24
Very fine – Miss Honeyman to dinner

Wednesday 24th 25
[Cheary?] day for Kendal. A three-day visit to see the Cooksons (see 29 October entry for her return).
Rain at night.

Thursday 27 26
cold & damp – rainy afternoon

Friday 28th
a lovely bright day – warm like spring.

Saturday 29
Fine afternoon [–] stormy ride, in Gig but pleasant with John Cookson. Left Elizabeth, The Cooksons’ chronically ill eldest daughter. as I found her, – poorly.

Sunday 30th
Very rainy, fierce wind. Went with D to see the Elliotts. Hartley to Tea &c

Monday 31st
Very fine morning – with Bertha to Low Wood &c – – Robinsons to Tea & cards

Tuesday, Novr 1st
Lovely mild morning. Rain comes on – Hartley to Dinner – Cards – T[om] R[obinson] – They stayed till ½ past 10

Wednesday 2nd
Blustering morning – walk on Terrace – sunny gleam – Fine colouring seen from Field. Cherry-trees &c – – T R. here [–] very bad cold[.] Cards again.

Thursday 3rd
Very rainy & stormy – never out but at Mr Robinsons in the Evening, & in the morning with B[ertha] & K[ate] at Waterfalls.

Friday 4th
One of the loveliest of days[.] Walked with B[ertha] & K[ate] to Low Wood. Came home in Chaise with Mr R[obinson] returning from Miss H K. Henrietta Kearsley, presumably a relative of Charlotte Kearsley Robinson. In Dora’s estimation, this visitor to the area was “very pretty but very insipid” ( LDW, 27).
– The [Autumn?] – till Tuesday or Wednesday – [ ] & [ ] – now [beautified?] [beyond?] [ ]. T. R. ill – Cards by ourselves – at night D & I called on Mr de Q.

Saturday 5th
Dull & wet – alas the Bonfire! The annual Guy Fawkes’ Day bonfire, thwarted by rain.
No walk / But Dora had.

Sunday 6th
Blustery showers – Mr Barber came to Dinner. I walked with him by Fox Ghyll to Ambleside – called at Miss Dowling’s

Monday 7th
Bright morning – closes in – Snow – Rain [–] sleet – Anne arrives Most likely their housemaid Anne Harrison, returning to service after a period of convalescence (see 19 October entry).
– walk only on Terrace – Sunny Bursts through the Day.

Tuesday 8th
Very cold – snow – sleet – walk in heavy rain
Wednesday blustery – ground covered with snow.

Thursday 10th
Hard frost – fierce wind. Southeys did not get off – [Fetched?] Julia from Ambleside – Miss Pritchards – gay cloaks[,] immense Bonnets Apparently details from a soiree hosted by their 69-year-old neighbor, Laetia Pritchard, at her Loughrigg home, Croft Lodge. Sara Coleridge mentioned a similar gathering in a November 1820 letter (">WT MS WLMS A / Coleridge, Sara / 3), and in June of that year, SH joked with her then-single cousin, Tom Monkhouse, “You may grow more beautiful every day, after you are married, and old Miss Pritchard, even, will not espy out the half of your charms” (LSH, 182–83). Miss Pritchard would pass away in January 1827 at age 71 (Miscellanea Genealogica et Heraldica 3 [1880], p. 154).

Friday 11th
Southeys off – fine frosty day – snow [mountains?], very grand – walked with Dora & Mr T. Robinson by Fox Ghyll to Ambleside. Willy poorly – when we came home.

Saturday 12th
The loveliest of bright days [–] to Ambleside for Willy – ill on Sofa – – sun shining[,] blinds down – –. Mr Barber [come?] ask me to walk after dinner – could not. Dora stayed so long on her ride –

Sunday 13th
Very cold – very dull & rainy afternoon – walked in rain to Grasmere.

Monday 14th
Robinsons to tea [–] a beautiful day – sunny & bright – garden clearing [–] to Mrs de Quinceys

Tuesday 15
The same lovely weather – I walked with D. We made calls – Willy rode with Mr Barber – cards at 8 o’ night – Mr & Mrs R –

Wednesday 16th Novr
Sara H[utchinson] arrived – showery day

Thursday 17th
Very stormy[.] Wm & M. arrived SH and WW had been away for six weeks, primarily at Coleorton, and MW for over two months (Letters, 4:404).
Friday 18th – Rainy – walked only on Terrace.

Saturday 19
Fine clean air – a shower or two – Rode in cart with new pony with Willy –
Sunday 20 Very wet – [ ] at Mr Robinsons – walked an hour in rain on Terrace with D – & alone
Monday – Stormy wind – showers. Dr [ ] in Evening – Walk with W & T[om] R[obinson] – Mr de Q. –

Tuesday 21st 22
Showery – Fine walk on Terrace by moonlight with W & T R

Wednesday 22 nd 23
T R departs – showers

Thursday 23 rd 24
Walked with Wm. round by Skelwith Bridge Hamlet three and a half miles south of Rydal on the other side of Loughrigg.
– various Calls

Friday 25th
Rain again – at night very heavy –

Saturday 26th
Still rainy & blustery

Sunday 27th
Snow showers. Hail – Sunshine. Wm. & M and Willy at Grasmere Church – walk with Mrs Carr

All this week neglected That is, neglected her diary, suggesting she was resuming on 3 December.
– Cold and stormy – – Walk every day –
Saturday 3rd William [Parker?] Funeral – snow on ground – foggy –
Sunday 4th – Cold – snow on ground – –
Monday 5th – Very bright – Sloppy roads – snow on ground – walked to Brathay with Wm. W[illy] followed

Tuesday 6th
Snow almost gone. Walked to Elter Water Village and small lake three miles southwest of Rydal, on the other side of Loughrigg.
– Wm & Mr de Q – Mr Huddleston Possibly Rev. Andrew Hudleston (1777–1851), perpetual curate of St. Nicholas in Whitehaven (Letters, 4:697).
– misty but pleasant

Wednesday 7th
To Wood The Wood, home of the Barlows. in Cart with D – back with Willy – very pleasant – Rain in evening.
Thursday 9 (8)th DW’s marking. – Lovely day – & rosy sunset – – I not well. The Rest with Mr Barber planning new house In the eventuality they would need to move from Rydal Mount. – He dines –

Friday 10 (9)th The final entry in this notebook and for 1825. She resumed her diary on 10 February 1826 in a new notebook (DCMS 104.2).
– Dull rainy morning – [Brewing?]. –

1825 Visitors this spring & summer
Mrs Coleridge & S[ara]. Mrs Hutchinson Mary Hutchinson, wife of Tom.
Mrs Elwood. Jane de Whelpdale Ellwood (b. 1780) of Penrith, an old friend of MW and SH whose husband, Richard, had passed away in 1811 (LSH, 140; MW, 52, 302; Letters, 3:406).
Miss [Whelpdale?]. Strickland
Cookson. Eldest son of the Kendal Cooksons. Miss Jewsbury. Miss Cookson Elizabeth Cookson, their eldest daughter.
Mr Quillinan. Edward Quillinan (1791–1851, DNB), the former army officer and future husband of Dora who had retired to Rydal in 1821 to live near his poetic idol, WW. In the wake of his wife’s tragic 1822 death, Quillinan and his two daughters had settled in London and Kent; but, by SH’s report, he returned to Rydal in late August 1825 for the consecration of the new chapel (WT MS WLL / Hutchinson, Sara / 2 / 110a).
Miss Honeyman See note for 7 October entry.
Mrs Barlow – Miss Barlow
Q[uestion]? – Plague in Florence 15431 This cryptic note appears upside down at the bottom of the back inside cover. DW’s query possibly grew out of her rereading of the Florentine poet Dante (see 13 December entry and note) and presumably concerned the Black Plague that ravaged mid-fourteenth century Florence (30 years after Dante’s death).
